author: bridge-bot
content:
<unnawut> re: **@ch4r10t33r**
> @Benewagner @tcoratger Would it be possible for the reference implementation to include a custom instantiation with a smaller lifetime (e.g. 2^10)? This would make it much easier to test accuracy and compatibility against the Zig implementation. At the moment, generating keys with a 2^18 lifetime is quite slow on older Macs.
Doesn't changing the ``key_gen()`` `'s 3rd param to other value work? From the hash-sig readme this would be changing `T::LIFETIME`` to 10:

```

let (pk, sk) = T::key_gen(&mut rng, 0, T::LIFETIME as usize);```

author: bridge-bot
content:
<Benewagner> re: **@unnawut**
> Doesn't changing the key_gen()`'s 3rd param to other value work? From the hash-sig readme this would be changing `T::LIFETIME to 10:


let (pk, sk) = T::key_gen(&mut rng, 0, T::LIFETIME as usize);
Yes exactly. The max lifetime (T::LIFETIME) for everything we test should be 2^32. the activation time can be much shorter.

author: bridge-bot
content: <Benewagner> The running time of key gen is  something like O(activation_duration + Log Lifetime).

author: bridge-bot
content: <Benewagner> But after the new PR is merged, it will be O(max{sqrt(Lifetime),activation_duration}).

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ch4r10t33r> re: **@unnawut**
> Doesn't changing the `key_gen()` 's 3rd param to other value work? From the hash-sig readme this would be changing `T::LIFETIME` to 10:


let (pk, sk) = T::key_gen(&mut rng, 0, T::LIFETIME as usize);
Yes, but this generates empty leaves for the other epochs, which results in a different hash from the zig implementation. I know, I can change the zig implementation also to do the same thing as the reference implementation. I was just wondering if there is a simpler way to compare.
